dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener from Astana writes in, asking if we could, uh, talk a bit more about the National Fund's operations and the recent economic meetings at the Akorda.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener from Astana writes in, asking if we could, uh, talk a bit more about the National Fund's operations and the recent economic meetings at the Akorda.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. President Tokayev just received the annual report from the National Bank of Kazakhstan, right? That was today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it covered a huge range of stuffâ€”monetary policy, the financial system, even the assets of the Unified Accumulative Pension Fund.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tokayev was briefed on the macroeconomic situation, key outcomes of the monetary policy, the state of the financial system, international reserves, and the assets of the Unified Accumulative Pension Fund (UAPF) and the National Fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The UAPF, yeah. It's a massive part of the country's savings. They also talked about inflation reduction and that new draft banking law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is so crucial, especially given that meeting he had back in April with Prime Minister Bektenov and Timur Suleimenov from the National Bank.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, President Tokayev held a separate meeting with Prime Minister Olzhas Bektenov, National Bank Chairman Timur Suleimenov, and other officials to discuss the economic situation amid falling global prices for energy and key commodities due to tariff conflicts.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At that time, Tokayev instructed the government and regional authorities to urgently finalize an action plan to respond to the financial and economic crisis, aiming to sustain growth and attract investment.
